data.title: Frost (2017)
data.meta_description: Rokas and Inga, a couple of young Lithuanians, volunteer to drive a cargo van of humanitarian aid to Ukraine. They cross the vast snowy lands of the Donbass region, drifting into the lives of those affected by the war.
data.text:
Frost is ilgesys the movie. This word cannot be directedly translated into English, but its Russian translation (toska) is beautifully summed up by the late Vladimir Nabokov: "No single word in English renders all the shades of toska. At its deepest and most painful, it is a sensation of great spiritual anguish, often without any specific cause. At less morbid levels it is a dull ache of the soul, a longing with nothing to long for, a sick pining, a vague restlessness, mental throes, yearning. In particular cases it may be the desire for somebody of something specific, nostalgia, love-sickness. At the lowest level it grades into ennui, boredom.”

Šarūnas Bartas made a war film that focuses on a modern…

First of all, I would recommend my friend Ash’s moving and articulate review of Frost where he does also acknowledge its shortcomings. He’s of Lithuanian heritage and has a strong cultural/historical background in Eastern Europe more broadly (presently finishing up a double major in anthropology and Russian). He recommended Frost to me, and I read his review before watching it, meaning my viewing experience was inextricably colored by his.

My first remark is about how remarkably advocative the film feels. Bartas seems to be delivering humanitarian aid like his tetchy, inexperienced youth protagonists. That aid is not in the form of footwear and food but a film. The quasi-cinema vérité style coupled with long passages depicting people mulling over the…
